title: 110_hr2306
content: The Act is titled the "Minnesota Chippewa Tribe Judgment Fund Distribution Act of 2007" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2 as findings and purpose. The Minnesota Chippewa Tribe filed claims before the Indian Claims Commission for an accounting of funds received and expended under the Nelson Act of 1889 and other statutes and treaties. The Minnesota Chippewa Tribe filed claims for additional compensation not covered by the Nelson Act of 1889. A settlement was approved by the Court, and $20,000,000 was transferred to the Department of the Interior for beneficiaries. These funds represent additional compensation that would have been distributed per capita under the Nelson Act. The Minnesota Chippewa Tribe filed claims for additional compensation not covered by the Nelson Act of 1889. A settlement was approved by the Court, and $20,000,000 was transferred to the Department of the Interior for beneficiaries. The judgment funds will be divided among the Bands based on enrollment numbers, with each Band developing a distribution plan for their share. The Secretary must submit a plan to Congress for approval as required by the Indian Tribal Judgment Funds Use or Distribution Act. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms including "available funds" as funds awarded to the Minnesota Chippewa Tribe, "Bands" as specific tribal bands, "judgment funds" as funds awarded in a specific court case, and "Minnesota Chippewa Tribe" as the collective tribes mentioned. The Act defines key terms including specific tribal bands such as Portage Band, Leech Lake Band, Mille Lacs Band, and White Earth Band, excluding the Red Lake Band of Chippewa Indians in Minnesota. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. Loan reimbursements are provided to certain bands under Section 4 of the Act. The Secretary is authorized to reimburse each Band for litigation expenses and expert witness fees incurred before June 22, 1999, related to Docket No. 19 and 188 before the U.S. Court of Federal Claims. Bands must submit a claim within 90 days of the Act's enactment, supported by invoices and receipts, certified as unreimbursed from other sources, and paid with 5.5% interest per annum. The Secretary will review and approve claims for reimbursement of fees and expenses incurred in litigation related to Docket No. 19 and 188 before the U.S. Court of Federal Claims. Approved claims will be paid from judgment funds before distribution under section 5. After reimbursing fees and expenses related to litigation, the Secretary will update Bands' membership rolls and divide judgment funds proportionally among them. Each Band will have a separate account for their share of funds. Bands will develop tribal plans for fund use or distribution. SEC. 6. DEVELOPMENT OF TRIBAL PLANS FOR FUND USE OR DISTRIBUTION: The Secretary must prepare separate plans for each Band's share of funds within 180 days. Bands can withdraw funds according to their distribution plan without liability on the Secretary. SEC. 7. GENERAL PROVISIONS. Funds disbursed under this Act are not liable for previously contracted obligations. All funds distributed are subject to the Indian Judgment Funds Distributed Act.
